awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: LTREB: Feedbacks between evolution and demography in severely fragmented prairie populations of the purple coneflower, Echinacea angustifolia
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will continue a long-term study of natural selection in the purple coneflower, Echinacea angustifolia. At the beginning of the 1800s, prairie covered a great swath of North America. Since then, about 99% of the tallgrass prairie has been destroyed. The small, isolated patches of prairie that remain harbor great biodiversity, yet rates of local plant extinctions are alarmingly high in remnant prairies. This project will advance scientific understanding of why some populations go extinct and others persist. Threats to prairie populations include fire suppression, declines of pollinators, inbreeding, loss of genetic diversity, and a reduced capacity to evolve by natural selection. This project builds on a long-term investigation of these ecological and genetic processes and feedbacks between them affecting a model prairie plant species. The purple coneflower typifies prairie plants in its long lifespan, often decades, and in other attributes. This study is the first of its kind to illustrate a population's capacity to adapt. In addition to advancing scientific knowledge and disseminating information to scientists and land stewards, this project will provide research experience and training to diverse participants at a level appropriate for their interests and career stage: high school, college, and graduate students, teachers, and citizen scientists in Minnesota and at the Chicago Botanic Garden.

The project uses formal quantitative genetic approaches and common garden experimental designs to quantify additive genetic variance for fitness, population differentiation, and inbreeding depression. Researchers will estimate the amount of genetic variation in Darwinian fitness of individuals planted in 2003, many of which flowered for the first time in 2015 using aster statistical models to analyze fitness data. Other experiments will estimate the reduction in mean fitness due to mating between siblings. Together with demographic censuses of remnant populations, started in 1996, these studies will yield comprehensive assessments of population growth rates and the potential for evolutionary rescue. A key strength of the research is that experiments are conducted in a realistic habitat, including interactions of the coneflower with its pollinators and herbivores. The core datasets comprise continuous individual fitness records, including annual survival and reproduction of over 17,000 plants in ten experiments and in 27 natural prairie remnants in Minnesota. These datasets, which will extend up to 30 years by the end of the project, offer a rare window into the interplay of evolutionary and ecological processes of a long-lived species.

por.por_cntn:
This project has continued a long-term study of the interplay of evolutionary and ecological processes in remnants of tallgrass prairie in Minnesota. Early in the 1800s, prairie covered a great swath of North America. Since then, over 99% of the tallgrass prairie has been destroyed through conversion to agriculture and urbanization. The small, isolated remnants of prairie that remain harbor great biodiversity, but they are subject to local plant extinction at an alarming rate. This project has advanced scientific understanding of consequences of fragmentation and other environmental change, including fire suppression, declines of pollinators, inbreeding, diminution of genetic diversity, and reduced capacity for ongoing adaptation in response to natural selection. This project has focused on Echinacea angustifolia, the still relatively prevalent narrow-leaved purple coneflower, a species that typifies prairie plants in its long lifespan, often decades, and in other attributes.

Our contributions. During the term of this award (2016-2022), we have evaluated how ecological and evolutionary processes interact and affect the persistence and ongoing evolution of fragmented Echinacea populations. We have shared our findings with other scientists, land stewards, managers, practitioners, and policymakers through publications in scientific journals, at scientific meetings, and in workshops. Among our key findings (details are presented in published articles, posted on our website, echinaceaProject.org):

1. An experiment that has been running for 20 years and is ongoing shows that our study population harbors extensive genetic variation available to support ongoing adaptation in response to natural selection. This finding counters a common view that genetic variation of this kind is likely negligible. Even so, it does not guarantee that the genetic variation is sufficient to support adaptation at a rate that will ensure the species' persistence as environmental conditions continue to change rapidly. We have established and monitored two additional experimental cohorts to assess the generality of our findings.

2. This and other components of the research have motivated our continued development of the statistical approach we established for rigorously quantifying lifetime Darwinian fitness of long-lived organisms, including perennial plants. This software package, called ?aster? in the open-source and free statistics environment ?R,? is proving to be invaluable to us and other research scientists for analyzing demographic and genetic processes in diverse populations.

3. In earlier work, we had shown that both spatial proximity and overlap in flowering time increase the chance that a pair of individual plants will cross-pollinate and produce seeds, but synchronous timing was the stronger influence. With this funding, we have demonstrated that fires (i.e. controlled burns) synchronize reproduction both among and within years, increasing mating opportunities and nearly doubling seed production. Correspondingly, we have documented increases in population growth rates with burning. This newly demonstrated mechanism by which fire can enhance plant reproduction may generally promote population growth and maintain plant diversity in fire-dependent biomes worldwide.

4.  We have monitored nearly a thousand individuals from their emergence as seedlings from naturally shed seeds through 7-10 years, documenting 11% survival through this period. Such precise insight into juvenile life history of a long-lived herb is extremely rare and greatly strengthens understanding of ecological and evolutionary dynamics.

5. To assess the potential for evolutionary change in seasonal flowering time, we have estimated the genetic variation in two phenological traits (flowering start date and flowering duration) for a cohort produced through open-pollination and growing in the wild, finding a heritability of about 20%.

In our work toward these outcomes, we have mentored scientists and educators and engaged many others in our activities, including many graduate, undergraduate, and high school students, high-school biology teachers, college professors, and many volunteers. They all learned science by doing it and helped advance understanding of population biology of long-lived herbaceous plants.

We maintain a website (http://echinaceaProject.org/) that helps disseminate results, organize datasets, and curate collections, such as our frozen seed bank, our insect specimens, and microscope images of pollen from prairie plants. The website provides information on how to improve the conservation and management of perennial populations in fragmented habitat. In addition, the website furthers our educational goals with links to educational materials and postings about internship and employment opportunities. We also keep project members, collaborators, and the public up-to-date on our lab and field activities with a blog and twitter feed and a page on facebook.

Under an additional NSF award, we are continuing this research. Please visit our website for current information on our activities and learn about our latest exciting findings!
